data.title: Clicking on a file in tree view causes an immediate crash
data.body:
Atom immediately crashes whenever I click on a file in the tree view or try to open a file when a particular git project is open in tree view.
- .ico & .gif files are fine, php, js, tpl, html, rb, and strangely .mp3 files all cause a crash

Details:
- Atom version 1.1.0
- successful repro in --safe
- Occassional traceback:

```
events.js:141
      throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
            ^
Error: write EPIPE
    at exports._errnoException (util.js:814:11)
    at process.target._send (internal/child_process.js:552:28)
    at process.target.send (internal/child_process.js:485:12)
    at global.emit (C:\Users\B06537\AppData\Local\Atom\app-1.1.0\resources\app.a
sar\src\task-bootstrap.js:54:22)
    at Object.console.error (C:\Users\B06537\AppData\Local\Atom\app-1.1.0\resour
ces\app.asar\src\task-bootstrap.js:20:21)
    at process.<anonymous> (C:\Users\B06537\AppData\Local\Atom\app-1.1.0\resourc
es\app.asar\src\task-bootstrap.js:67:22)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at process.emit (events.js:169:7)
    at process._fatalException (node.js:219:26)
```

This problem doesn't occur unless I've added a particular git repo folder or subfolder, but then effects every other project folder once it's been added.

Important notes:
- Context menus don't appear in tree view unless I'm right clicking a folder or file directly

![atomerr](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5964658/10837170/ad2ee5a2-7ef9-11e5-9417-5d560ff4b25d.png)

_(After really digging into this issue, the following seems irrelevant as the real culprit may have been a surreptitious (read: automatic and completely silent) update to atom v1.1.0, but I'm leaving this in here for the sake of thoroughness)_
Activity up till the issue occured:
1  disable jshint package
2  instal linter-eslint package
3  try to use linter-eslint (throws error: linter package dependancy)
4  install linter
5  try to use linter-eslint (throws errors:
     - missing local config, using global config
     - cannot evaluate string as javascript due to unsecure-eval setting?
       \* w/stack trace but no submit issue button <-- first weird problem)
6. This is about where I lost the ability to open new files in tree view, though opening them from menus works.

data.title: Always opens previous project. Even with settings changed.
data.body:
I discussed it with someone here: 
https://discuss.atom.io/t/open-empty-editor-on-start-does-nothing/22127/6

...and I was told that this PR might have something to do with it. 
https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/8397

data.title: Native application
data.body:
(I apologize in advance if this is not the right place to ask. Please feel free to close immediately if not appropriate here.)

Please, are there any plans in very distant future to move away from web-based application stack (Node, JS, Chromium, ...) to the more native technologies like Skia, Cairo, Scintilla, Cocoa, ..?

I'm mostly asking about the editing component, whether it wouldn't make sense to implement it with native drawing library, instead of DOM.

My only motivation to ask such question is the belief that such move would make Atom editing more responsive and performant.

Thanks!

Is it bug in atom or in some plugin?

data.title: [FR][Meta] Split UI and "core"
data.body:
The idea is very simple (but doing it would probably cost a lot). What this feature request is is a proposal for splitting the UI from the "core" part of the editor in such a way that the UI and the core would communicate via an abstracted communication channel (be it some sort of signals/events when on a local machine, be it via network when on a remote machine, etc)

Let me define the terms that I'm using:

UI: the visual part that we use too interact with Atom. Panes, tabs, editor, tree view, etc...
core: the _thing_ that does file management (open/close/save files), holds unsaved buffers, performs searching in the FS, etc.

In other words, The UI would be the `V` and the `C` and the core would be the `M` if I had to describe that thing with a `MVC` example.

Such a split would allow Atom to:
- edit files remotely (like vim/emacs over ssh)
- connect to another Atom core and interact with it (collaborative editing between 2+ people)
- speed up Atom (tricky, First launch won't have any speed boost, but multiple instances won't need to do the entire startup process, but only search for an already available core and bind to it)
- make Atom's UI bullet proof (an UI crash, which is still a thing, won't close opened files nor lose unsaved buffers, as those would be living in the core instead of the UI)
- probably more

data.title: Add section on reporting bugs to contributing guide
GitHub Markdown syntax highlighting bug for bash codeblocks
data.body:
It seems like the syntax highlighting for bash code blocks "leaks out" when using the `GitHub Markdown` syntax highlighting.

Seems to be triggered by the keyword `if`.

![https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/u3nhh3tiffs6spc/2015-10-29%20at%2014.33.png?dl=0](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/u3nhh3tiffs6spc/2015-10-29%20at%2014.33.png?dl=0)

data.title: (ctrl + backspace) or (ctrl + del) unexpected behaviour
data.body:
in this case

``` javascript
container.hover(func, /*cursor here*/                              func2);
```

when I hit (ctrl + del) I expect it to delete all spaces before 'func2', but I get 'func2' deleted too. It's really annoying. Other text editors like sublime behave correctly in this case.

data.title: Add option to toogle the wrap guide
data.body:
I don't know if this belongs here or into the [specific repositiory](https://github.com/atom/wrap-guide).
It would be nice if the [wrap-guide](https://atom.io/packages/wrap-guide) package could be toggled via Command Palette or menu (_Edit_ -> _Toggle Wrap Guide_).
I've disabled the package because it bothers me, but sometimes I need it.
Actually you have to navigate to the settings view, search for the wrap-guide package and enable/disable it all the time.

data.title: No way to turn off Line Wrapping
data.body:
I'd like to turn off the soft line wrapping in Atom, there seems to be a few options that have to do with soft wrapping whitespace, but none seem to make it so an entire line of code will not wrap.

![issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/180963/10811920/488a8eca-7dce-11e5-8e6b-a7adc65b70f7.png)

data.title: Tree View bug when opening multiple files from command line.
data.body:
If I open a single file with Atom from a command line (atom some_file.cpp), it opens Atom, displays the current directory and its contents in the Tree View and displays the file which was passed as the argument.  So, everything works properly.

![bug1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5036152/10810884/facd443a-7dc2-11e5-8d81-806998dfc207.JPG)

However, if I open multiple files (atom some_file1.cpp some_file2.cpp some_file3.cpp), it opens Atom, display the files which were passed as the arguments, but does something strange in the Tree View:

![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5036152/10810846/5c05040a-7dc2-11e5-8e33-52c907fed9ef.JPG)

As you can see, instead of the current directory and its contents, it displays each file from the argument list as a directory.  However, they're all empty.  If I close the displayed files, there is no way to re-open them by clicking those empty directories.... they're just empty artifacts.  If I right click and show each of those directories in the explorer, it opens the proper current directory in the explorer.  If I right click and choose to open in the new window, it'll open a new instance of Atom with the selected file displaying and proper Tree View on the left.

Note that this only occurs if you are doing this with existing files.  If any of the arguments is a non-existing file, then you get a mixture of the two cases:

![bug2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5036152/10810930/a06015ee-7dc3-11e5-9a09-00e09f4c3127.JPG)

If all of the arguments are non-existing files, then proper Tree View is displayed, as none of the files actually exist, so they're just displayed and need to be saved.

I've tried this on two different machines and its the same result.  So, sounds like a bug.

Windows 7 SP1 & Windows 10
Atom 1.0.19

data.title: Crashing when opening a file and minimizing a folder
data.body:
When I open a file called ball.dts, leave the window open, and then close the folder named items that is 2 folders away, the editor crashes. That is the only one that I can close and it crashes, other files don't do anything. When I change tabs, or close the folders except for items, it also doesn't crash. 

(I can't check the file size right now)

data.title: Atom hangs on large directories/files and when window switching
data.body:
I used the command `atom .` to open the root level of a large SVN-controlled project. Atom takes a fairly long time to open this, and is laggy while trying to scroll through/open directories using the file explorer. In addition, opening a large file (say, an 1800 line shell script) takes longer than it should. Further, if I open the large file, then switch to Chrome, then switch back, the editor often freezes forcing me to wait several seconds before giving me the ability to scroll/edit again; often it simply crashes the editor.

Is this a known bug/being addressed at all? I feel like I can't be the only one this is happening to.

OSX 10.10.5
MBP 2012 (2.5GHz Intel Core i5, 8 GB RAM)
Atom 1.0.19

data.title: Mb windows npm3
Can't fetch packages when backspace character in username, Windows
data.body:
I made my username the backspace character `` (`Ctrl`+`Backspace`, on Windows 7), which I think is the reason to why Atom can't fetch packages.

Here are some screenshots: http://imgur.com/a/Wk0ik

The install path in the last image does contain a backspace character, only it's not visible; ...`are installed to C:\Users\\.atom\packages`

This is on Windows 7 :checkered_flag: , Atom v1.0.19

data.title: Close tab when splitting it into a new pane
data.body:
Is it possible when I right-click a tab and select split-{up,down,right,left} to have that tab close, since I now have two tabs open with the same file (the original and the new split pane)?

Don't know if this is possible today - haven't found any package for it.

data.title: Atom background transparency
Attempting to a specific project folder via Application: Add Project Folder adds home directory instead
data.body:
**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a directory `~/test-dir`
2. Launch `atom --safe`
3. File > Add Project Folder
4. Navigate to ~/test-dir and add it

**Expected:**

`~/test-dir` is added as a project folder

**Actual:**

`~` is added as a project folder

**Notes:**
- I've experienced this problem on both Atom 1.0.8 and 1.0.19, but only on my work PC (Ubuntu 12.04).
- I have had to resort to using [project-manager](https://atom.io/packages/project-manager) to handle all project folders on my work PC which handles project folders just fine
- Repeating steps 2-3 seems to attempt to re-add `~` (which does nothing)

data.title: Introduce NativeCompileCache
data.body:
This PR speeds up source code compile times by using a hacked version of the `vm` module (https://github.com/as-cii/cached-run-in-this-context).

We've been searching very hard for a way to make startup faster: the biggest low hanging fruit seemed to be `vm.runInThisContext` which, before this improvement, took more than `250ms-300ms`. That function is used inside `Module.prototype._compile` for, surprise, compiling the source code: although v8 compiler is quite fast already, our codebase has grown quite a lot and the more files we added, the worse the situation would get.

The snapshot approach tried in #9265 should have indirectly solved this, but it felt way too complicated to construct an `AtomEnvironment` inside the snapshot context. Instead, we are taking advantage of a v8 compiler feature that allows to speed up source code compilation by producing/consuming a cache blob. By using this mechanism, we have managed to change startup times from (without any tab open):

![screen shot 2015-10-28 at 11 51 42](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/10786490/c2df5476-7d6a-11e5-8f77-e089911f33f8.png)

to:

![screen shot 2015-10-28 at 11 48 05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/10786493/c6248cfa-7d6a-11e5-85eb-b2e2563aec6f.png)

:tada: :tada: :tada:

There's still some aspect we could improve, such as where these cache blobs get stored: I used files as the storage mechanism, as it allows us to keep the code pretty simple, but they take ~40ms to get read. There are alternatives to this (e.g. asar), but I am not sure it would improve the situation that much: even a 50% improvement, would make this just ~20ms faster at the expense of making code a bit more complex.

Please, note that whenever DevTools are open, v8 seems to make this optimization a bit worse: if you, however, spawn Atom:
- via cmd;
- by running the executable;
- by reloading the window with DevTools closed;

You will notice the speedup. @zcbenz: any ideas why this happens? I guess this covers already 100% of the average use cases and won't matter to the end user, but if possible it seems to be still worth investigating.

After this lands, I will go on hunting other things that are slowing startup down: we feel like IO could be the main cause but we'll get a better picture after this improvement gets :ship:ped.

/cc: @atom/feedback @nathansobo

data.title: Atom freezes momentarily when deleting a variable
data.body:
![oct 28 14 52](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5358503/10784369/b22b946e-7d83-11e5-940e-f85d733fc7d0.gif)

Editor freezes for a few seconds when deleting a variable(or symbol?). 

Atom v1.0.19
OSX El Capitan 10.11

data.title: CTRL+R freezes Atom
data.body:
Pressing CTRL+R in order to jump to a method in a PHP file freezes Atom version 1.0.19.

No extra plugins installed, only core.

data.title: Not able to set Atom as the default text editor on Windows because there's no folder containing the latest binaries
data.body:
Setting up Atom as the default text editor on Windows is a pain in the ass.

The Windows installer installs it to `%LOCALAPPDATA%\atom\`, and there's a bin folder there, which contains nothing less than a command script to run Atom, that is updated everytime a new Atom build is downloaded to your computer.

The issue here is that AtomInstaller does not install Atom in a way that you can easily tell what binary file is the most up-to-date one. For every version downloaded, you just have a folder in the install dir that looks like `app-1.0.19`.

A fix for this would be to have the most up-to-date binaries being installed to a folder on `%LOCALAPPDATA%\atom\` called **current**.

And yes I know I can use the script (atom.cmd) as the default text editor, but me and most of the people wouldn't like our default text editor to be a script.

data.title: Remove keyPath as a possible return value on the event object for onDidChange in config.coffee
data.body: Updated the documentation for onDidChange in config.coffee. The value is never returned on the object so the documentation was updated to reflect that. Should close https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7918

data.title: Atom vertical line between curly brace
data.body:
Hello, sorry for the bothering, but i installed atom 1.0.19 and i can't get the vertical line between two curly brackets when i'm inside a function, the line in the red ellipse in the image(the photo is not of my version), is absent from my installed version and i can't get, i searched for a package but i didn't find, please if some one help me with a name of a package to added it or a configuration, and sorry for my bad english

data.title: Curly brace marked even inside comment
data.body:
In C/C++ or java like languages, even if the starting curly brace is commented, it is selected when the cursor is taken to the ending curly brace.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11350803/10772753/ed1529c0-7ccd-11e5-9679-f7fbdbdfa453.png)

data.title: Clicking next to the filename triggers "Copied:" without copying it
data.body: At the bottom status bar, the current filename is shown, and if you hover over it, it becomes underlined and the mouse becomes a pointer. If you move the mouse to just above or below the filename but still on the status bar and click, then the "Copied: <filename>" tooltip appears, but without actually copying the filename to the clipboard.
